case_name: Wife and three sons of Daulatram Hukamchand v. Official Assignee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 197 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 197 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 6,1954,

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated August 6,1954, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 30 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 6,1954, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 30 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated January 28, 1954,

facts.text: Appeal No. 30 of 1954 arose out of judgment and order dated January 28, 1954, of Bombay High Court in Insolvency No. 74 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 28, 1954, of the said High Court in Insolvency No. 74 of 1951. 1385 C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, S. N. Andley and J. B. Dadachanji, for the appellants.

facts.text: Respondent official assignee took out notice of motion under s. 55 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act against appellants for declaration that deed of gift executed by insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of appellants was void.

anchor.surface_text: by special leave arises from the notice of motion taken out by the respondent official assignee under s. 55 of the Presidency towns Insolvency Act against the appellants for a declaration that a deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void.

facts.text: Creditors of Daulatram filed petition in Bombay High Court, Insolvency Case No. 74 of 1951, for adjudication of insolvency as he gave notice of suspension of payment of debts on August 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some creditors of Daulatram filed a petition in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, Insolvency Case No. 74 of 1.951, for an order that the said Daulatram be adjudged insolvent as he had given notice of suspension of payment of the debts on August 2, 1951.

facts.text: Daulatram was adjudicated insolvent on August 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Daulatram was adjudicated insolvent on August 21, 1951, with the result that the estate of the insolvent vested in the respondent under s. 17 of the Act.

facts.text: Estate of insolvent vested in respondent official assignee under s. 17 of the Act upon adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that the estate of the insolvent vested in the respondent under s. 17 of the Act. On September 26, 1951, the respondent took out the present notice of motion.

facts.text: Respondent took out notice of motion on September 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1951, the respondent took out the present notice of motion. The impugned deed of gift has been executed by the insolvent in favour of his wife and three sons who are the appellants before us.

facts.text: Deed of gift executed by insolvent in favour of his wife and three sons who are the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned deed of gift has been executed by the insolvent in favour of his wife and three sons who are the appellants before us. In reply to the notice of motion appellants I to 3 filed a joint affidavit setting out the facts and circumstances under which the said deed of gift had been executed by the insolvent in their favour.

facts.text: Appellants 1 to 3 filed joint affidavit claiming deed was transaction supported by valuable consideration, not falling within s.55.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the notice of motion appellants I to 3 filed a joint affidavit setting out the facts and circumstances under which the said deed of gift had been executed by the insolvent in their favour. In substance, the appellants case was that, though the document purported to be a gift, it was really a transaction supported by valuable consideration and as such it did not fall within the mischief of s. 55 of the Act.

facts.text: At hearing before Mr. Justice Coyajee, appellants sought to lead evidence, respondent objected under s.92 Evidence Act, objection overruled, evidence allowed.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this notice of motion before Mr. Justice Coyajee, when the appellants sought to lead evidence in support of this plea, the respondent objected and urged that the evidence which the appellants wanted to lead was inadmissible under s. 92 of the Indian Evidence Act. The learned Judge, however, overruled the respondents objection and allowed the appellants to lead 1386 their evidence.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Coyajee did not accept appellants' contention and granted declaration under s.55 on January 28, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the end the learned Judge did not accept the appellants contention and, by his judgment delivered on January 28, 1954, he granted the declaration claimed by the respondent under s. 55 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeal No. 30 of 1954 before Chagla C.J. and Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment and order the appellants preferred an appeal No. 30 of 1954 which was heard by Chagla C. J. and Shah J.

facts.text: High Court held Mr. Justice Coyajee erred in allowing oral evidence, held s.92 barred it, dismissed appeal on August 6, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges took the view that Mr. Justice Coyajee had erred in law in allowing oral evidence to be led by the appellants in support of their plea that the transaction evidenced by the deed of gift was in reality a transfer for consideration. The learned Judges held that the gift in question had been executed by the donor in favour of the donees out of natural love and affection and that, under s. 92, it was not open to the appellants to lead evidence to show that the transaction was supported not by the consideration of natural love and affection but by another kind of valuable consideration.

facts.text: High Court did not consider oral evidence on merits.

anchor.surface_text: On this view of the matter the learned Judges did not think it necessary to consider the oral evidence actually led by the appellants and decide whether Mr. Justice Coyajee was right or not in rejecting the said evidence on the merits. That is how the appeal preferred by the appellants was dismissed on August 6, 1964.

facts.text: Application for certificate rejected by Bombay High Court on September 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1954, the application made by the appellants for a certificate was rejected by the High Court at Bombay

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on November 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: but special leave was granted to the appellants by this Court on November 3, 1954, and that is how the appeal has come before us for final disposal.

facts.text: Appellants are wife and three sons of insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned deed of gift has been executed by the insolvent in favour of his wife and three sons who are the appellants before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.92 Evidence Act does not apply as official assignee is not representative in interest of insolvent.

anchor.surface_text: If that be the true position, before considering the effect of the provisions of s. 92 in regard to the appellants right to lead oral evidence, it would be necessary to examine whether s. 92 applies at all to the present proceedings between the official assignee who is the respondent and the 1389 donees from the insolvent who are the appellants before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court decree and remands appeal for disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them. It appears that the attention of the learned Judges who heard the appeal in the High Court at Bombay was not drawn to this aspect of the matter. That is why they proceeded to deal with the question about the admissibility of oral evidence led by the appellants on the assumption that s. 92 applied. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the court of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

holdings.text: s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them. It appears that the attention of the learned Judges who heard the appeal in the High Court at Bombay was not drawn to this aspect of the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Official assignee not representative in interest of insolvent; doctrine of mutuality makes s.92 inapplicable between party and stranger.

holdings.text: s. 92 cannot apply to the present proceedings between the respondent and the appellants

anchor.surface_text: If that be the true position, s. 92 cannot apply to the present proceedings between the respondent and the appellants and so there can be no doubt that the respondent would not be precluded from leading evidence of an oral agreement for the purpose of contradicting, varying, adding to or subtracting from the terms of the impugned document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Official assignee acts for creditors, not insolvent; analogous to creditor applications where s.92 does not apply.

holdings.text: the official assignee also cannot be said to be the representative-in-interest of the insolvent in these proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the object with which s. 55 has been enacted, the nature of the proceedings taken under it, and the nature and effect of the final order which is contemplated under it, it is clear that, like the creditor who may apply, the official assignee also cannot be said to be the representative-in-interest of the insolvent in these proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.55, assignee challenges transfer for creditors' benefit; property already out of estate; higher title than insolvent.

holdings.text: the answer to this question must be in favour of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by Shri Purushottam which still remains to be considered is whether the appellants who undoubtedly are the representatives in interest of the insolvent can avoid the application of s. 92. In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of mutuality; s.92 exclusion applies only between parties reciprocally; stranger vs party allows evidence by both.

holdings.text: ss. 91 and 92 really supplement each other.

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by this argument. As we have already observed, ss. 91 and 92 really supplement each other. It is because s. 91 by itself would not have excluded evidence of oral agreements which may tend to vary the terms of the document that s. 92 has been enacted

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.91 proves contents; s.92 governs variation; neither excludes without the other.

holdings.text: We do not read s. 99 as laying down any such prohibition by necessary implication.

anchor.surface_text: We do not read s. 99 as laying down any such prohibition by necessary implication. As a matter of fact, from the terms of s. 92 itself, it is clear that strangers to the document are outside the scope of s. 92 but s. 99 has presumably been enacted to clarify the same position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.99 clarifies strangers' rights; does not impose prohibition on parties independent of s.92.

holdings.text: The rule of exclusion enunciated by s. 92 applies to both parties to the document and is based on the doctrine of mutuality.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of exclusion enunciated by s. 92 applies to both parties to the document and is based on the doctrine of mutuality. It would be inequitable and unfair to enforce that rule against a party to a document or his representative in interest in the case of a dispute between the said party or his representative in interest on the one hand and the stranger on the other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reciprocity required for estoppel by document terms; inequitable against party when stranger not bound.

holdings.text: We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the court of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the court of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erroneously applied s.92 and did not consider merits of evidence.
